title: Principles of Environmental and Occupational Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHPC2009.
description: This public health oriented course addresses how the environmental and occupational (work-related) factors affect human health and what we can do to prevent or minimize the negative impacts. Whereas environmental science tends to address how human beings affect the environment, this course focuses on how the environment affects human health. Topics include an introduction to major categories of environmental hazards that impact population health; environmental epidemiology methods in assessing the impact of environmental exposures on human health; the evaluation and control of common hazards in the work place; and the impacts of global environmental changes on health.

title: Hong Kong Health Care System
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: Healthcare systems are complex and multidisciplinary in nature. They need to meet population needs and may include a network of services such as prevention, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and health maintenance provided to individuals of all ages and with a range of needs. This course is an introductory course on basic definitions and functions of health care systems. Using case studies and discussions, students will be able to develop understanding of practice and resources in health care.

title: Contemporary Health Issues
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: We are living in a highly complex and interdependent world. Health of the population is not only affected by local environment and individual behavioral choices, but also by other factors that are of regional and international origin. This course will introduce various major contemporary health issues that are threatening the health of people around the world, and the strategies that are being used to tackle these issues.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Describe the top threats to global health: including the causes, current status, and the impact on people’s health around the world;2. Describe the strategies that are being used, or being proposed, to mitigate the impact of the health threats
syllabus: 1. Course introduction2. Noncommunicable diseases3. Weak primary health care4. Fragile and vulnerable settings5. Air pollution and climate change6. Climate change challenges7. Impact of human decision on health8. Dengue9. HIV, Ebola and other high-threat pathogens10. Global influenza pandemic and COVID-1911. Antimicrobial resistance12. Vaccine hesitancy13. Sustainable Development and Health
required_readings: To be advised by the course teacher
recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

title: Health Education and Health Behaviours
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHPC2016
description: The objectives of this module are teaching students the concept of health in relation to health education and health promotion in community. Different behavioral theories, models and approaches will be explored. This module will also look into how health promotion practice links to different models of health behaviours . Through understanding of factors related to health behaviour, modifications for healthy lifestyle can be planned within the social and cultural context. Students will learn how to put theory into practice.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: 1. Acquire knowledge on the most common theories, models, and approaches used in studying health-related behaviours  2. Apply the theories into promoting health-related behaviours with the respective groups
syllabus: 1. Scope of health behavior and health education; Theory, research and practice in health behaviour and health education2. Self-Determination Theory3. The Transtheoretical Model4. The Theory of Planned Behavior and the Integrated Behavioral Model5. The Fear Appeal approach, the Extended Parallel Process Model and The Health Belief Model6. Elaboration likelihood model of persuasion7. The Social Cognitive Theory8. Social network and Social support9. Stress, coping, and health behavior10. Ecological models of health behaviour11. Diffusion of Innovations
required_readings: Textbook: 1. Health Behaviour: Theory, Research and Practice (5th edition). Edited by Karen Glanz, Barbara Rimer and K Viswanath. Published by Jossey-Bass Inc. US 2015
recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

title: Foundations of Health Promotion
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHPC2016
description: This course will provide a fundamental introduction to health promotion and needs assessment. Different approaches and models to health promotion will be introduced to students. Students will apply the models to assess and report the health needs of a community through both primary and secondary data collection and analysis.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Understand basic principles of health promotion 2. Understand different health promotion models and tools 3. Conduct needs assessment for health promotion
syllabus: 1. Overview of Health Promotion2. Health promotion basics Health Promotion Planning Models I3. Health Promotion Planning Models II 4. Ethical issues in health promotion5. Assessing needs for health promotion6. Needs Assessment: Use of Secondary Data7. Needs Assessment: Use of Primary data8. Basics in analysing and reporting data

title: Biostatistics for Community Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken COMM3110, DSME2010, 2020, 2011, 2021, ECON2121, GRMD2102, PHPC1015, PHPC2015, PSYC2010, SEEM2430, SPED2600, STAT2101, 2102, 2001 or 2006.
description: This course will introduce the basic biostatistics concepts for public health practice. Emphasis will be placed on conceptual understanding of statistical approaches to public health data rather than on theory and equations. To enable students to acquire a set of analytical skills to deal with various public health questions, the course will focus on analyzing common types of public health data, and introduce exploratory and confirmatory biostatistical methods. The biostatistics concepts will be taught together with a user-friendly software SPSS through detailed, illustrative examples.

title: Epidemiology for Community Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHPC1014 or PHPC2017
description: This course aims to provide a basic understanding of the fundamental principles of epidemiological methods and their applicability to the field of health research.

title: Settings-Approach for Health Promotion
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: Community health intervention is putting more emphasis on modification of health risk behaviours and building up the personal, cognitive and social skills which determine the ability of the individuals to gain access to, understand and make use of the information to promote and maintain good health. In many countries, there is a well-structured health care system to address diseases and illnesses but there is no system addressing health particularly on promotion of positive health. Healthy Setting is a value-based approach which has the ability of translation into language to fit the context of the particular setting. The concept of Healthy Setting is evolution from Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion by building healthy public policy, re-orientation of health services, strengthening community actions, building up personal health skills and health advocacy. This module will discuss the role of different settings in promoting health of the population. Students will gain basic understanding of healthy cities, health promoting school, health promoting workplace and other common settings.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students should be able to:1. Understand the paradigm shift of community health intervention moving beyond traditional health boundary;  2. Acquire the basic concept of setting approach for health promotion and learn how to adopt the concept for community health intervention;  3. Identify the potential settings for health promotion;  4. Select the appropriate tools for needs assessment and evaluation;  5. Acquire sufficient knowledge and skills to assist in developing community health intervention programme using the setting approach.
syllabus: 1 Introduction to Settings Approach for Health Promotion (I)2. Needs Assessment in Healthy Settings3. Programme Planning and Evaluation in Health Settings4. Schools as Health Settings5. Conducting Needs Assessment for Course Project6. Health Promotion in Health Care Organisations7. Health Promoting Workplace8. Concept of the Healthy Cities9. Health Promotion in Other Settings10. Visiting Health Promotion in Settings

title: Health Communication
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This module will discuss various communication theories and their application in health promotion message design.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Demonstrate and work with in-depth theoretical knowledge  from the area of health communication and critically analyse, evaluate and synthesise concepts, strategies, and cases from  various disciplines, such as, communication, public health, psychology, sociology, and so on, to generate ideas for effective health communication  2.  Apply knowledge and skills in developing and creating health communication campaigns; exercise appropriate judgement in  the effects of various media and/or user-generated content on public beliefs about health issues and evaluate the effectiveness of health communication interventions;3.  Participate constructively in group discussions and make formal and informal presentations to specialised and non-specialised audiences on the objectives, strategies, and outcomes of the health communication campaigns conceived in class as part of a group project; use multi-media skills in creating and presenting the campaigns

title: Research Methods in Community Health
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This module will focus on using mixed research methodology (quantitative, qualitative) to study community health practice. Students will learn how to develop appropriate tools for studying the desired health topic and translating the evidence into practice.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1.Acquire techniques and develop tools for quantitative research, e.g. questionnaire design, choosing appropriate measures, techniques of survey interview, coding and preparation of quantitative data;  2. Conduct qualitative study, e.g. focus groups, in-depth interviews

Sample size, sampling, and response rates for quantitative research4. Practical issues in questionnaire design5. Techniques of survey interviewing6. Ethical issues for research; Workshop on qualitative methods

title: Management of Non-Governmental Organisations
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This module will discuss the management and operation of non-governmental organisations (NGO) of varying sizes.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1.Understand the role of NGO in the society and how they complement the mainstream services;  2.Acquire the basic knowledge and skill to work in NGO.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to NGO Management2. Governance and internal control of NGO3. NGO capacity-building4. Preparing for change5. Managing for change

title: Social Marketing Methods
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements: Not for students who have taken PHPC3026
description: Physical inactivity, unhealthy diet, smoking, people nowadays are often living an unhealthy lifestyle. Education and the rule of law have been used in attempts to change people’s behaviour with limited success. Social marketing is a systematic planning process that utilizes commercial marketing techniques to change people’s behaviour and achieve social good. The primary difference between social and commercial marketing is that the ultimate goal for commercial marketing is financial gain, whereas for social marketing, it is societal gain.This course will focus on the social marketing planning process, which includes scoping, target and behaviour selection, understanding of facilitators and barriers, and design of social marketing campaigns.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to:1. Explain the importance of target-centred programme planning;2. Explain why a particular group is chosen as the priority segment;3. Identify the type of factors that affect people’s decision to change their behaviour;4. Explain the importance of campaign positioning and how to develop a unique position;5. Develop interventions that can facilitate behaviour change by using strategies from the marketing mix.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to social marketing2. Segmentation3. Understand the priority segment4. Describe the priority segment5. Competition 6. Positioning7. Marketing mix I: Product8. Marketing mix II: Price9. Marketing mix III: Place10. Marketing mix IV: Promotion11. Finding the right mix12. Final presentation: Solution to the problem
required_readings: Textbook: Lee NR and Kotler P. Social marketing: Behavior Change for Social Good. 6th edition. Sage. 2020
recommended_readings: To be advised by the course teacher

title: Community-Based Rehabilitation and Self-Care Management
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: Although health advice and/or education is routinely given in day to day consultation with health professionals, more intensive self-management programmes should be designed for better control of chronic illnesses. Care in community is way forward for sustainable development of health care system. Patients including their caregivers need to be better equipped to maintain their functional capacity at optimal level. Students will learn the fundamental principles and concepts of community based rehabilitation by improving the health status of people with chronic visceral disability so they would live independently as far as possible. Students will also learn the skills to empower patients and families in self-management of chronic illness in community setting, and improving their health conditions.

title: Health Promotion Planning and Evaluation
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
requirements:

description: This course aims to provide a practical introduction to health promotion project planning. Successful health promotion project requires careful planning in order to increase project effectiveness and efficiency. Great health promotion project also takes into account the impact of project design on long-term generalizability and sustainability. This course will guide students through the process of planning a health promotion project, including developing project goals and objectives, choosing suitable intervention strategies, designing monitoring and evaluation methods, budgeting and timetabling.

Describe real-world examples of how Intervention Mapping was used in different countries around the world    3. Draft a health promotion proposal

title: Food Security : Global and Local Perspectives
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: Despite the advancement in economic development and food technology, there are people living without the basic supply of sufficient and clean foods require for their physiological well-being. The World Food Summit of 1996 defined food security as existing “when all people, at all times, have physical and economic access to sufficient, safe and nutritious food to meet their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life”. This course introduces the factors affecting the sustainability of the contemporary food systems at both global and local perspectives. Areas including natural and manmade disasters, technological advancement, economic drive, political stability, as well as socio-cultural influences will be analyzed critically as insights to tackle the challenge of future food crisis. The concept of food safety will be introduced as a sub-topic of food security.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Understand in detail the definition and scope of food security  2. Apply the understanding of food security to the analysis of global and local situations of food and nutrition supply  3. Realise the global effort in improving food insecurity and the promotion of food sufficiency for vulnerable populations in the local perspective  4. Understand the role and importance of food safety to human’s health and the steps of its protection mechanisms
syllabus: - Introduction to food security and food safety- Food system in the 21st century- Factors influencing the food system- Impact of food security on human health- Food security in Hong Kong and China- Global efforts to achieve food security- Guest speech: Food security in developing countries – the case in Vietnam- Chit-chat with Oxfam Hong Kong food insecurity among low-income population- Ensuring food safety to promote food security- Food borne illnesses and human health- Food safety control from production to consumption- Food laws and regulations

title: Mental Health as a Public Health Issue
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: The course aims to enhance students’ knowledge on mental health and its determinants in public health and psychological perspectives. Major components of the course include 1) the epidemiology of mental health problems;  2) relationships among sociocultural factors, interpersonal resources, individual characteristics, and mental health; 3) mental health issues after adverse life events; 4) concepts and theories related to mental health promotion in the community; and 5) community health services and interventions to improve mental health.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  1. Understand the relationships among sociocultural factors, interpersonal resources, individual characteristics, and people’s mental health  2. Apply basic concepts in public health and psychological theories to understand the determinants of people’s mental health  3. Demonstrate understanding on mental health issues among urban people, at-risk populations, and people with negative life experience.  4. Familiarize themselves with current interventions and community services to improve people’s mental health.

Community mental health services and interventions

title: Practicum in Community Health Practice I
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This module provides the opportunity to practice the theories and skills learned in the programme. Students will explore the mission, vision and values of their placement site and the health needs of their serving communities. This module will prepare the students for their next field placement (CHPR4902).
outcome: With a solid foundation in health promotion theories and methods, the most important process that community health practice students must undergo prior to their transition into public health professionals is to learn the expected attitudes, behaviours, work ethics and responsibilities required of a public health practitioner in the community. This opportunity is valuable for students to apply their acquired knowledge and skills when they participate in health promotion or health service activities in a community setting. The objective of this course is to facilitate the students in understanding the vision, missions, values and responsibilities and the populations served by the designated community organization..
syllabus: 1.       The first module of the two-part practicum begins with a briefing which focus on advising students about things they need to be mindful of prior to being engaged in the field.    2.       Each student will be asked to select from a list of collaborating health promotion agencies as their practicum setting. These agencies include (but are not limited to) those that regularly employ individuals with a health promotion background, such as health education centres, non-profit health advocacy groups, hospitals/clinics, worksite wellness centres, and special population groups.  3.       Prior to the engagement of practicum, each student must discuss his or her potential role and responsibilities with the assigned agency supervisor within two course terms (including CHPR4902) based on the major needs of the agency. The student’s involvement in a meaningful contributing role is strongly encouraged. Upon the end of this discussion, both parties will be asked to complete and sign an official form detailing the expectations on the students and the goals/objectives of their involvement.

title: Practicum in Community Health Practice II
academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
description: This module is a continuation of CHPR4901 and will provide opportunities for experiential learning for students in community settings related to health promotion or health service. This experience is designed to place the students into a real work setting and be part of a team with other community health workers and provide opportunities for the students to apply their acquired knowledge and skills as they participate in health promotion or health services activities of designated community organizations.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: 1. Apply knowledge and skills learned from taught courses as they participate as a working member of a community organization; 2. Assist in the design, execution and/or evaluation of health promotion or health service activities of relevant health organizations.
syllabus: Student involvement in any activities or projects for this module should consist of no less than a total of 220 hours before the end of the term, the distribution of which is up to the discretion between the student, agency supervisor, and campus supervisor.
